is a popular beach destination in

Although Choroní is generally known as one of Venezuela's best Caribbean beaches, the hamlet itself actually sits slightly inland, boasting some fine colonial houses around a quiet central plaza. Instead, it is the neighbouring fishing village of Puerto Colombia just beyond Choroni where the palm tree-lined beaches lie and most accommodation is found. Framed by the tropical rain forest of Parque Henri Pitier, the beaches around Puerto Colombia are some of the most stunningly beautiful in the country.
, buses leave the terminal every couple of hours for Choroní (more at weekends), wending through the dense mountainous cloudforest of the

. The 45-km road is very narrow and full of hairpin bends - at some points the bus has to stop and reverse a few yards in order to negotiate the bend in two manoeuvers. It is not a journey for the faint-hearted. The alternative - taxis - is little better as drivers race into blind bends with little concern for oncoming traffic. Driving your own vehicle may be preferred but extreme caution is needed on the roads. The journey is about 2 hours by bus from Maracay or 1.5 hours by car.
The size and small streets of Puerto Colombia mean cars are best left at the
. Everywhere can be reached on foot. To reach the most beautiful beaches you need to hire a small boat, or "lancha." Cepe (30 minutes away) or Chuao (20 minutes) are popular options.

content=Clean, decent and roomy, with ample parking. 8 rooms, of which 3 have their own bathroom and others share. Communal TV room. Proprietor Sr. Francisco Suarez.

content=Budget-Mid Range posada with 4 double rooms, swimming pool surrounded by hammocks and fruit trees. All rooms with private bathroom, hot water, mosquito nets.  Breakfast included.  Superb service from posada owners - they go out of their way to help.
